Intuition is very much a real thing

So basically:


Hindsight Bias: Hindsight bias is a psychological phenomenon that allows people to convince themselves after an event that they had accurately predicted it before it. Suppose your friend starts eating the pizza that's been in the fridge for the past week and you tell him "week-old pizza cause psychedelic hallucinations" but he eats it anyway and soon start to wig out. You'd say "Dude, I told you so".
But if you are wrong and he's totally fine, you probably won't even think about it ever again. This is known as 'Hindsight Bias" or the "I-Knew-It-All-Along" phenomenon. This doesn't mean the common sense is wrong, it just means that our intuitive sense more easily describes what just happened, than what will happen in the future.
"We also tend to perceive order in random events, which can lead to false assumptions." For example, if you flip a coin five times you have equal chances of getting all tails as you do getting alternating heads and tails. But we see the series of five tails as something unusual, as a streak, and thus giving that result some kind of meaning that it very definitely does not have.
That is why we have the methods and safe-guards of psychological research and experimentation which basically save the study of our minds from the stupidity of our minds like hindsight bias and perceiving order in random events.
Steps of Psychological Research:
Take for example we are researching "Can week-old pizza cause psychedelic hallucinations? Does coffee make you smarter? Or does it just make you do dumb stuff faster?"
-Operationalizing the Questions: Figuring out how to ask general question about your subject and turn them into mesurable & testable propositions.
-Theory & Hypothesis: Any Scientific method starts with a question and a theory is not a hunch like "a quad-shot of espresso makes you think better"). Theory is what explains and organizes lots of different observations and predicts outcomes. And when you come up with a testable prediction, that's your hypothesis.
-Replication is key:
Once your theory and hypothesis are in place, you need a clear and common language to report them with, so for example, defining exactly what you mean by "thinking better" with your espresso hypothesis will allow other researchers to replicate the experiment.
And replication is key.
You can watch a person exhibit a certain behavior once, and it won't prove very much, but if you keep getting consistent results, even as you change subjects or situations, you're probably on to something.

Describing behavior without manipulating it and making connections and predictions from those findings:
Describing Behavior:

-Case Studies:
Case studies take an in-depth look at one individual. They can be misleading because by their nature, they can't be replicated, so they run the risk of over-generalizing.
However case studies are good at showing what can happen and end up framing questions for more extensive and generalizable studies.
They're also often memorable and a great story telling device psychologists use to observe and describe behavior.
For example, say the smell of coffee make someone anxious and irritable doesn't been that it has the same effect on everyone. In fact, the person may have terrible memories associated with that smell, and so his case is actually quite rare.
But you would still have to look at lots of other cases to determine that conclusively.

-Naturalistic Observation:
In naturalistic observation, researchers simply watch behavior in a natural environment. The idea is to let the subjects just do their thing without trying to manipulate or control the situation.
Like case studies, naturalistic observations are great at describing behavior, but they're very limited in explaining it.

-Interviews & Surveys:
Psychologists can also collect behavioral data using surveys or interviews, asking people to report their opinions and behaviors.
While carrying out a surveys it's important
-How you ask:
Surveys are a great way to access consciously held attitudes and beliefs, but how to ask the questions can be tricky; subtle word choices can influence results.
For example more forceful words like "ban" or "censor" may elicit different reactions than "limit" or "not allow".
-Who you ask:
And if how you phrase surveys is important, so is who you ask.
For example the result of asking a room full of students at a pacifist club meeting what they think about arms control, be a representative measure of where students stand, because there's a pretty clear "sampling bias" at work here. To fairly represent a population, a random sample is required where all members of the target group, in this case students, had an equal chance of being selected to answer the question.
So once you've described behavior with surveys, case studies, or naturalistic observation, you can start making sense out of it, and even predict future behavior.

Correlation:
One way to do that is to look at one trait or behavior is related to another, or how they correlate.
Suppose a person thinks that his refrigerator is actually some kind of time machine that can preserve food indefinitely and because he was hungry he ate the leftover pizza that may have had a little bit of fungus on it.
Suddenly, he starts seeing things: green armadillos with laser beam eyes.
From here we could deduce that eating unknown fungus predicts hallucination, that's a correlation.
-Correlation is different to Causation: Correlation is not causation though.
Though it make sense that the hallucinations were result of the questionable fungus, the person may be already on the verge of a psychotic episode and those fuzzy leftovers were actually benign. There there could be an entirely different factor involved, like maybe he hadn't slept in 72 hours, or had an intense migraine coming on, and one of those factors caused his hallucinations.
It's quite tempting to draw conclusions from correlation but it's important to remember that correlations predict the possibility of a cause-and-effect
relationships; they cannot prove them.
So we've talked about "how to describe behavior without manipulating it and how to make connections and predictions from those findings".

Experimentation:
Experimentation really get to the bottom of cause-and-effect behaviors. Experiments allow investigators to isolate different effects by manipulating an independent variable, and keeping all other variables constant, or as constant as you can.
This means that they need at least two groups:
-Experimental Group: which is gonna get messed with.
-Control Group: which is not gonna get messed with.
Just as surveys use random samples, experimental researchers need to randomly assign participants to each group to minimize potential confounding variables, or outside factors that may skew the results.
-Double blind procedure:
Sometimes one or both groups are not informed about what's actually being tested.
For example, researchers can test how substances effect people by comparing their effects to placebos, or inert substances.
And often, the researchers themselves don't know which group is experimental and which is control, so they don't unintentionally influence the results through their own behavior, in which case it's called, you guessed it, a double blind procedure.

So let's put these ideas into practice in our own little experiment.
Let's me and my friend are debating Caffeine's effect on the brain.
Personally, my friend is convinced that coffee helps her focus and think better, but I get all jittery like a caged meerkat and can't focus on anything.
And because we know that overconfidence can lead you to believe things that are not true, we decided to use some critical thinking.
Question: So let's figure out our question: "Do humans solve problems faster when given caffeine?"
Testable prediction: "Adult humans given caffeine will navigate a maze faster than humans not given caffeine."
Independent Variable: The caffeine dosage is your independent variable, the thing that you can change.
Dependent Variable: the thing that depends on the thing that you can change is going to be the speed at which the subject navigates through this giant corn maze.
Experimentation:
Control Group: So the control group gets a placebo, in this case decaf.
Experimental group one: Experimental group one gets a low dose of caffeine, which we'll define at a 100 milligrams; just an eye opener, like, a cup of coffee's worth.
Experimental group two: Experimental group two gets 500 milligrams, more than a quad shot of espresso dunked in a Red Bull.
Once everyone is dosed, we turn them lose in the maze and wait at the other end with a stopwatch to measure the results from the three different groups and compare them to see if there were any conclusive results.
If the highly dosed folks got through it twice as fast as the low dose and the placebo groups, then our hypothesis was correct, and she can rub my face in it saying she was right all along, but really that would just be the warm flush of hindsight bias telling her something she didn't really know until we tested it.
Then, because we've used clear language and defined our parameters, other curious minds can easily replicate this experiment, and we can eventually pool all the data together and have something solid to say about what that americano was doing to your cognition– or at least the speed at which you can run through a maze.

ONLINE COURSE NAME –PSYCHOLOGICAL RESEARCH
In this video we learn how to apply the scientific method to psychological research. Lots of ways, but today Hank talks about case studies, naturalistic observation, surveys and interviews, and experimentation. Also he covers different kinds of bias in experimentation and how research practices help us avoid them.

TOPICS COVERED IN THIS VIDEO:-

1. The Scientific Method

Scientific method is about how to ask general questions about your subject and turn them into measureable testable proposition.
The scientific theory works on a question and a theory, once a testable prediction is reached it is called the hypothesis.
After a suitable hypothesis is reached an experiment can be conducted for testing the hypothesis.
2. Case Studies

This is a type of research which take an in depth look in one individual. They can be sometimes misleading because by their nature they can’t be replicated. They run the risk of over generalising.
3. Naturalistic Observation

This is a method where researchers watch behaviour in a natural environment. The idea is to let the subjects do whatever they want without manipulating or control the situation.

4. Surveys and Interviews

In this process the people are asked to report their behaviours and reports. Surveys are a great way of getting access to peoples consciously held attitudes and beliefs. There is a sample bias and sample data which is collected and then the results are generated.
5. Experimentation

By this method it allows the investigators to isolate different effects by manipulating an independent variable and keeping other variables constant. It contains 2 groups namely the experimental group(which is to be messed with) and control group(which is not going to be messed with).
6. Proper Research Practices

Consent of others and proper practices like testing, analysing, predicting and result generation codes are followed for proper prediction of psychological behaviour.

Have you ever looked back on history and wondered how people could believe the things they believed? Are we immune to backward thinking?

I think, overall this is a great video, and entertaining! But, I'm concerned about his take on the scientific method. He states theory comes before hypothesis. I understand this is how it is being taught right now, and I believe it's turning psychology into a cool kids club. Meaning, if you have the correct hypothesis, the one that is cool right now, you'll interpret you're data the acceptable way. Not necessarily, the accurate way. All data must be interpreted. And it's so easy to unknowingly infuse our biases into the interpretation. How do we humbly keep ourselves from doing that?

When I was a kid, science teachers always said hypothesis comes before theory. I think in hard science type texts, this is still taught. This way, you were starting with no presumptions that colored the data. I'm concerned if you put an unproven theory first, that theory will color the gathered data. Basically, you're using an unproven theory as the foundation to build the facts upon.

Example: Theory: I believe the lightening god will strike the bad people.
(Lightening storm comes and strikes several people.)
Gather data: I found bad things about these people. Because of my underlying theory bias, I expected to find bad things, therefore I did. If you look hard enough, you'll find what you are looking for.
Conclusion: We have proven, through factual data, and longitudinal studies conducted through dozens of storms, that the lightening god strikes bad people.

Silly? Not really. Take our postmodern myth we've clung to, hoping to explain our existence.

Theory: Evolution wants us to procreate, giving us an underlying compulsion toward sex, which must be fulfilled or we will suppress our id, causing imbalance in our person. (Keep in mind, none of this is scientifically proven. Just speculation.)
Hypothesis: Men sleep around and look at porn because evolution has given them a compulsion, which if suppressed, will cause unhealthy balance in their person.
Gather data: Men do sleep around and look at porn. We can do study after study. This is what we expected, based on our theory bias. Therefore we don't really have to think of many different explanations. We don't need an open mind. We just jump closemindedly to our conclusion.
Conclusion: Men need to express themselves sexually, because evolution, and women who ask their men to not look at porn are oppressing and suppressing them in an unhealthy way. Because science. Do you see how the underlying evolutionary bias colored the way the data was interpreted? I didn't make this up.
This was an article recently published in Psychology Today.


This sounds legitimate to someone with a secular evolutionary bias just like the lightening god sounds legitimate to someone believing in the lightening god. Neither are science. Science starts with hypothesis, not theory.

Or an example from Thomas Jefferson:

Theory: White people are superior to black people in reasoning and work ethic. (Sadly, he actually believed this.)

Gathered data: On the plantations the black people do the bare minimum in reasoning and work. (Well, duh, it was free! They were kidnapped! Why the heck would they go out of their way to do their best? But because of his bias, he was blind to this option. Starting with a theory makes a person biased.)

Conclusion: We shouldn't let black people vote. (Wha?!)
This is what happens when we put the theory before the hypothesis. It causes us to see our data through biased eyes. It encourages us to filter the data through the biases of our own time period. Our time period is platonic, individualistic, and steeped in Naturalism. When we start with theory we allow all these biases in. In order to remain a powerful tool, science was stay objective.

Let me quickly begin with a little praise, you guys are doing a phenomenal job and should be recognized with an award, unfortunately they still don't give Nobel prizes in education, if they would I'm sure you'd get nominated at least 35 times ;) hard luck, but seriously fantastic series not just on psychology but pretty much all your content is top notch.
Now to my issue, which is with your maths: probability of tossing heads or tails 5 times in a row is not equal to a probability of getting mixed results, 5 tails would be 1(total number of desired outcomes) divided by all possible outcomes in this case 32 as in 2(number of possible outcomes in a single throw) to the power of 5(number of repetitions). Even if you consider both heads or tails to be a desired outcome that brings our chances from 1/32 to 2/32 = 1/16. Since all probabilities in a system have to add up to 1 we can easily calculate that all other outcomes have a probability of 15/16 (1-1/16) so as you can see you have a 15 time higher chance of getting a mixed result than to get 5 heads or tails in a row, although on each throw chances of throwing head or tails are still 1/2 which can lead to an awful lot of confusion, often, so please don't encourage it ;)

Just a note on the probability theory at 1:25: The probability of getting "all tails" in five coin tosses is not equal to the probability of getting "alternative heads and tails". To be more exact, the probability of getting alternating heads and tails is exactly double of the probability of getting all tails: There are two events in which you can get alternative heads and tails. The first event A, is the case where you get "H T H T H". The second event B, is the case where you get "T H T H T". If you want the probabilities to be equal, you have to be a bit more specific and say something along the lines of "The probability of getting all tails in five coin tosses is exactly the same as starting with a tail and then getting alternating heads and tails."

Hey CrashCourse the correlation example is so wrong! Two things are correlated when you can consider the casuality relation in both way and the spurious correlation. Since you say that "Bob was on the verge of a psychotic episode and the fungus was harmless", the fungus and the hallucination can't be considered as correlated. If they were, the B point would have been "the hallucination made him eat the fungus since he altered his choice".

A good correlation example is the pretty common relation between ice-cream and shorts. During summer, lots of people wear shorts and eat ice-cream. You can think that wearing shorts makes you willing of eat ice-cream, or that eating ice-creams makes you willing of wearing shorts. However, shorts and ice-creams are a pretty common spurious correlation since they're both caused by the hot temperature.

This video does mislead about the probability of getting all heads or tails in a row. It's 0.5 each time, yes, but not in a row. It's 0.5^x with x = the number of times you get the same flip. So three heads in a row is 0.5^3 = 0.125. This is not the same as 0.5

You do NOT have equal chance of getting all tails as you do getting alternating Heads or Tails. There is only 1 possible way of getting All Tails (TTTTT), and 2 possible ways of getting alternating (THTHT or HTHTH). If you merely meant that previous results won't affect future results, you're correct tho.

I know this is an old video, but wanted to address the significance of coins, heads or tails. I think this was slightly mistated but can be easily forgiven since this is not a video on maths.

If you are going to flip 5 coins and your GOAL is to achieve all heads... then getting all heads is significant. It is not true that getting all heads is the same as getting any other specific combination unless by that you mean also getting that combination in order. For instance specifically getting H H T T T vs two H and three T.

The odds of getting H vs T is 1/2 (presuming a perfectly balanced coin). 1 in 2 chance. Same with getting T. If at the outset your goal is to achieve 5 H, your chances are 1 in 2^5 or 1 in 32 OR 1/2*1/2*1/2*1/2*1/2.

However, if you flip 4 coins and get H H H H then before the 5th flip you say.. My goal is to get H making H H H H H... the chances are not 1 in 32 that you will get a H but rather it is 1 in 2.

I think the above is what you were trying to describe as briefly as possible?

My explanation to help people understand why this is true is to look at all past events are completed. So after I flip H H H H... the chances that my last flip was a head is 1 in 1 (1/1) not 1 in 2 because there is one possible outcome (bottom number). My chances that my last flip was a T is 1/0 or, in other words, we're trying to ask what is the probability that something will happen which is not a possibility. SO... when you are about to flip that 5th coin and want to know the probability that you will get a 5th H... you just use the above formula only replacing the probabilities above with the probabilities stated in this paragraph: 1/1*1/1*1/1*1/1*1/2 or 1/2.. there is a 1 in 2 chance of getting H on this fifth flip not 1 in 32 chance as some people might imagine.

We actually have more of a chance of getting alternating heads and tails than all tails because he didn't specify which it would start on, therefore there are two different ways in which this could occur.

It should be more like this:

Control Group (Decaf), Low Dose Group (1 cup), Medium Dose Group (Equivalent of 2 Cups), High Dose Group (Equivalent of 4 Cups). The amount of caffeine should not exceed this much for safety reasons, and the High Dose group is still at risk for unsafe reactions to that amount of caffeine.

You should test for how each dose of caffeine affects those completing the maze, and how consuming those doses over different time frames will also have an effect, as someone in the High Dose group may navigate the maze differently if they drank that amount over a longer period of time.

You should also record whether or not those groups even complete the maze. Some groups may get stuck, and may even need assistance out of the maze if they cannot complete it themselves. That should be recorded just as times completing the maze should be recorded. Some groups may be able to complete the maze in similar amounts of time to others, but may react to the maze itself in a lot more negative way, and could be more prone to crying or feeling stressed when they take longer than they wanted to or expected they could, even if that length of time isn't long at all.

Okay, let me see if I have this right. Correlation means that we have observed a progression from Occurrence-1 to Experience-A. It could be that O-1 causes E-A. We can't say for sure. All we can say is that there is a correlation between the two, but a correlation is only a potential connection. So, Peter Parker gets bitten by a radioactive spider, feels woozy and feverish, and then the next day exhibits spider powers. We can say that there's a correlation between getting bitten by a radioactive spider and developing spider powers. But one might not lead to the other. There may be other components involved. Perhaps Peter is a mutant and developed spider powers with no help or hinderance from the spider, its bite being just a coincidence. Before we can say for sure that getting bitten by a radioactive spider gives you spider powers, we'd have to subject many randomly selected students (and others maybe) to radioactive spider bites. If we see a consistent development of spider powers, then we can finally say that O-1 causes E-A. Is that right? (If so, then "correlation" is a strange bit of terminology because its syntax makes it sound like you're saying there's something there when what you're really doing is saying there could be something there. Wasn't there an English major available when that term was coined?)

1:26 5 tails is unusual because of probability, when you flip the coin the probability of heads or tails is 50% for each flip, but the probability of getting the same result each time goes down because you are multiplying the odds of getting one result by the odds of getting that same result each coin you flip. Therefore the probability of getting 5 heads in a row is 3.125%  (0.5 * 0.5 *0.5 * 0.5 * 0.5) not 50%.

I really wish you would have gone into a lot more detail on qualitative methods. Psychological research is not only quantitatively minded, particularly dealing with phenomena concerning meaning-making mechanisms. Quantitative measures do a very poor job at getting to the heart of a person's understandings. This is where psychology goes beyond biology. Psychology transcends biology and chemistry by acknowledging that it is dealing with people, not just natural systems. The point at 1:20 about coin probabilities is not technically true.  The probability of T-T-T-T-T is, in fact, equal to the probability of T-H-T-H-T (as the visual shows), but the probability of getting "alternating heads and tails" (as Hank's voiceover says) would also include the chance of getting H-T-H-T-H.

This means, strictly speaking, that "the probability of getting all tails" is exactly one-half the probability of getting "alternating heads and tails," because there are two ways to get alternating heads and tails, but only one way to get all tails.

Couple of other things people might be interested in:
1) Having a random sample which is representative of the population is tricky so a large proportion of psychology research is done on undergraduate psychology students (which means we understand ourselves REALLY well)
2) Data is only accepted as supporting a hypothesis if it meets the p<.05 significance level. This means that there is less than a 1 in 20 (5%) chance that the results are due to chance rather than due to the hypothesis being correct. So, in Hank's coffee experiment, a statistical test of the differences between the groups would need to be done to check whether it meets the significance level.

I don't think these examples of hindsight bias are strictly correct. If you make a clear and definite prediction that turns out to be right, it's not amiss to say "I knew it all along." Hindsight bias is: you never made a prediction, but after knowing the outcome you're convinced that it's what you would have predicted.

The bias described at 0:29 is confirmation bias: you notice when your predictions turn out to be right and ignore when they don't, and so develop an unwarranted confidence in a particular hypothesis, or in your predictive powers generally.

Two minor issues with this or at least points that need to be covered in my opinion. First thing is a minor correction which, at 7 minutes the claim is made there there must be at least 2 groups however, this is only if your experiment is a between subjects design (comparing subjects scores to other subjects) there is experiments which are within subjects design wherein subjects are tested twice under both variables thus leaving only one test group. In your example of maze running a within subjects design would have the subjects run a maze under no caffeine stimulation then run another maze with minor stimulation then a third maze with with heavy stimulation. Within subject designs are important for setting up certain experiments. The second point is very minor about your experiment. I know it's an example however, my experimental design professor would not be happy with me if I did not make mention to the fact that your experiment doesn't test solely cognition. There is the confound of caffeine's effect on athletic performance which may effect the results of your study. Cognition as your dependent variable was not properly isolated. Please control of confounds in experimentation before publishing research. Well, I followed you pretty well till the final example.

Your scientific study would prove nothing whatsoever. There is a second independent variable that you failed to take into account; the speed at which each individual naturally navigates the corn maze.

You could have a bunch of people that are good at navigating a maze in the experimental group while you have a bunch of people in your control group that are not. 

This would skew your results into complete uselessness. You have not eliminated all outside variables, which is the fundamental problem with modern-day psychological research.

Richard Feynman described this exact problem in his speech at Cal Tech in 1974 entitled Cargo Cult Science.

Hey. I know this might be my Psychology-graduate brain being picky, but you've missed a very important part of the scientific method. You can't just observe that one group performed better and draw your conclusions. You need to use statistical analysis to determine that the differences in your results couldn't have happened by chance. I know it's picky, but it's a pretty vital part of the process. It's the bit you can point to and say 'I was right' with scientific integrity.

I think the 'correlation does not imply causation' bit was incomplete and unfortunately so, because this popular phrase could use some explaining. In the example, the danger was that the pizza - laser ghost correlation was spurious. But this is 'easily' addressed through sample size and hypothesis testing.
The popular phrase is usually applied to caution against drawing conclusions after significance has been found. And that's where it becomes annoyingly inaccurate because a significant correlation actually does strongly indicate causation. It's just that generally it could be of three types: A to B, B to A, or C to both A and B (it could also be a mixture). Hank's example doesn't help to illustrate this because only one of these is plausible here.

Statistically it is less probable to have 5 consecutive heads or 5 consecutive tails than it is to have any randomized mixture of heads and tails. One of my favorite lecturers recently went on a rant about the 'increasingly empiricist nature of psychological research', and although I didn't necessarily agree with his overall point per se, he did make a fantastic argument. He proffered the idea that psychology should conduct it's research in an entirely different manner to the other sciences, as it is a subject quite unique in the sense that, irregardless of topic, psychology is engaged with the task of making a model of a model maker. Unlike other disciplines, it is fundamentally orientated around the tool which you are using to view the world, and as such you will alway posses biases, expectations and hindering subconscious beliefs. 
I don't agree that this means we should step away from empirical research (moreover, I think it bolsters it's worth, so to speak), but I thought it was a bloody good point.

With the experiment as you explained it, the subjects would need to complete 2 mazes, one before drinking the coffee, and one after. Otherwise you have no way to compare the effects of caffeine, as one subject may simply be better at doing mazes regardless. Then you can compare the differences in time with each subject individually as a percentage, average the percentages for each group, compare the groups, and form a basic conclusion. The more people in your experiment, the more data you can collect, and you can even try using groups with daily and non-daily "caffeinated beverage drinkers" to get a better idea of how caffeine effects people who don't have it in their system. They may feel jittery, where a daily drinker may feel more alert, and this could make a difference in how they complete the maze. Good luck, I hope this helps

As a psych student, I have all this extra super fun info about everything Hank's saying, so I'm going to write it because LOOK LOOK I KNOW THINGS I'M LEARNING THINGS
-It's always super important to check how an experiment has been operationalised, because the media will report an experiment as something like "Fear makes you a better liar!", when in the study "Fear" was operationalised as "The participants heart rate per minute before an anticipated shock", which could be a sign of fear for some participants but not for others. 
-Another necessary feature of a theory or hypothesis in psychology apart from being replicable is that it has to be fallible i.e. it has to be able to be proven wrong. If a theory is infallible, it's completely useless, because proving it right doesn't mean anything (except that you have a really general theory). 
-The way you phrase a question can also influence a person's memory of the event they're being questioned about. If you watch a car crash, and when questioned by a policeman they ask "How fast was the car going when it crashed into the other vehicle?", you're more likely to say it was going faster than if the policeman asked "How fast was the car going when it hit the other vehicle?"
-One of the reasons you run double-blind studies is because of something called the "Confirmation Bias". This is where you (usually subconsciously) influence the outcome of an experiment or source information for your experiment that will support your original hypothesis, therefore proving it right. So it probably would've been better for Hank and Bernese to ask a third uninvolved party to construct and run the experiment, so that neither of them could influence the outcome with their preconceived perceptions.

Not to be too much of a nit picker here, but flipping a coin 5 times and getting tails each time is twice as likely as getting alternating head and tails (3.125% vs. 6.25%).  The reason is that there is only one combination that will give you all tails (TTTTT), where as there are two ways to make an alternating combination (HTHTH and THTHT).  Doesn't really apply to the lesson I just like to point out minor mistakes by others to make myself feel better :)

The example experiment suffers from bias due to demand characteristics. The participants can easily figure out what the experimenters are studying, so they could act in favor or against the hypothesis being tested. To eliminate this bias and establish experimental realism, the experiments would need to implement a cover story.

I only have 2 problems with the finals experiment; 1. No one was asked when they last had caffeine 2. No one was asked how much coffee they drink on average. Both of these would effect results in regards to the amount given. So Hank that is an inconclusive experiment.

I don't think that corn mazes are an accurate variable for caffeine-to-intelligence. The caffeine could very easily just make them move faster, and with no effect on their intelligence, they would simply take the same moves but faster, giving them an advantage that has no connection to intelligence. A better variable would be a turn-based, skill-based board game, i.e. checkers or hearts, with turns-to-win instead of time-to-win being your final results. I realize that this isn't the point of the example in the video, but I think it should still be said.

@Koppa Dasao If you are expecting replication of results in the sense of a mathematical formula like physics or chemistry, then you will be disappointed by psychology. Psychology studies show replication in the same way that ecology or most biology studies do, by obtaining similar results. The similarity, as opposed to perfect replication, is due to our limited knowledge of all factors involved and the inability in most cases to perfectly replicate the method.
